This is one of those games that completely turn me off. I played it once and I was ok with it, but then I played again and I made a misplay in the first age, I was thrust into last place because of that with no way to do anything to recover.

The rage mechanic also(plus the fact people can steal rage) completely kills the game for me. It's supposed to be a constraint but it feels more like I'm getting locked into choices because of what can happen in any given age.

If you are new to this game it can be a miserable experience as anyone with experience has somewhat of a clue what to do and you might not notice how badly they are messing your plan up. In my first game I completely messed up a guys plan by not taking an action which cost him the game(he played optimally otherwise) but since I didn't fight he could not fight and his game was set back big time. It honestly feels worse than monopoly to me and that is my most hated game.

When you play with 4-5 people the game gets rather long and it makes me want to just play shorter games with similar player numbers.

I would much rather play games like Bunny Kingdom, Ethnos or 7 wonders which are similar
Worst game ever.
Runaway leader problem. Also very random on the cards you get in the draft each turn. With all the hype I expected more - very disappointing.

I played this game once. After the first of 3 rounds, I honestly thought we had the rules incorrect, as the game was so bad that I was certain that we had missed something.

The only reason this game is rated so well is because of the miniatures. This is the worst game I have ever played within the strategy genre.
Nothing wrong with game. I'm sure its a splendid affair. However after watching run through and or reading reviews, absolutely no desire to play.
So boring

This is a broken game. You win this game every time if you get all your players into the Ragnarök and lose the most battles. Winning battles is the worst thing you could do as a Viking Warrior apparently... The theme of the game does not work at all with the mechanics and scoring. I would think that the winner would be the last one standing, but what would I know.
Extremely imbalanced abilities, solved lazily with quick fix method of drafting as usual.
random, no fun

Seemed promising when learning how to play, but playing with others was a very boring experience. I was in a game with more experience players, and as a beginner, I felt like I stood no chance.

The options and cards felt boring. The unit placements on the map felt unengaging. The battles were anti-climactic. Knowing what was strong and when to play things were completely unknowable to a newbie.

The miniatures are okay. The map does not look great. The map actually makes the game feel tiny.

Some cards definitely felt stronger than others.

I felt the game is best appreciated by veterans. However, I felt the game did not have a theme or art style I liked. I can tolerate a Viking theme, but this game just did not do it for me.

Although the game appears to be full of intense combat, the actual combat events are lackluster and have no oomph.

Not a game I would seek out to play.

The game lasted a bit longer than I wanted, especially since I felt clearly in last place when I played against experienced players. I could not find a worthy redeeming aspect.

***Sell

Kind of a weak hybrid drafting and area control game. Sort of incentivizes you to lose more than win combat which I find strange, and the drafting isn't fantastic.

Valhalla, Ragnarock, and some crazy awesome minis though.

Loki/10

The rules or regulations of the cards are not well specified or written, they cause conflicts and encourage cheating. Entertaining game but it's not a big deal.
Saled

Rating after first play highly subject to change. Engine building, synergistic drafting games aren’t really my thing, nor are heavy themes and miniatures, still the gameplay was interesting, clever and seemingly well balanced

2/5

expensive game for what it is. the minis are great, but the game relies on a card system to play and win. experienced players dominate newer players. the balance on this game is way off due to broken strategies and poor playtesting.

I don't generally love area majority ("dudes on a map") games (with a few big exceptions), though this had a few mechanics that made it a bit more enjoyable for me. I, for one, like the twist of being able to essentially score points for the number of fighters than end up dead (i.e., "in Valhalla"). But at the end of the day, it's still very much an area majority game that didn't totally resonate with me.
Not worth the time or effort

At this point, I just don’t understand the lasting appeal of this game. Mechanically, it’s a weak closed drafting game of dubious balance and even more dubious fun. Sure, the dolls are nice, but the game around the dolls is a dull affair. I recently got suckered into a play after a long absence, and spent the entire time wishing I were doing something else. From now on, it’s gonna be a no from me, dawg.

the fact that the drafted cards change each round really hampers the first few plays or if there is a long time between plays. this to me is the sign of a bad game especially because there are not any components for players to build a long term strategy. this game needs player aids similar to those in kemet imo.

I don't like watching you continue to take your turn with the resources I had build up to be able to do what I needed.
Somewhere between Meh and Hated It. Just another dudes-on-a-map game. Generic circle of "terrain" to fight over. Card play makes any kind of planning a fail.

The game mechanics are pretty much broken. Some cards are vastly over-powered. Winning battles early gives you a huge advantage and if you lose, there's very little you can do to catch up in later rounds. One of the worst games I've played.

Avoid Cmon games. Terrible publisher and also avoid erics games. He was very offensive when met at a con!

1 demo play, with two rules incorrect (we played that the winner of the battle gets the reward regardless of who initiates the pillage, and without an initial province destroyed) so take it with a grain of salt.

Viewed as a thematic game, it very much limits the range of conflict and drama that can actually occur. Very few pieces in each location, all powers are relatively incremental (with exceptions like the giant that kills everyone at his location.) It's a curious choice for what should be The Ultimate in Theme.

As a strategic game, the card-drafting multiple-path-to-victory doesn't really appeal to me. The connections are fairly obvious (if you get all the points-for-dead-stuff upgrades and the kill-your-own-stuff, you will probably win.) A mix of cards seems a good idea; you don't even have the pleasure of very diverse strategic paths, as would ideally be the case.

I feel it's a hybrid design that takes the worse elements of thematic games (lack of depth, special powers on cards) and strategic (multiple paths to victory, surprisingly low interaction, combo engine pieces).

I love card-driven area control games, heavy conflict and Norse mythology... but I bounced off this one, hard. The game felt hollow, the card play repetitive, the interaction banal. Combat is fundamentally about playing cards to make a bigger number: hardly the stuff of legend. I know there is more scope for clever play than I intuited in my handful of plays, but I simply cannot find the motivation to put the effort into something so bland. I can't help but feel everyone is too busy swooning over miniatures to notice how empty the game is.

I played this game thinking I was going to be amazed. Didn't happen. Yes, this game has cool minis, but they come unpainted and detract from gameplay. Dice Tower really pushed this game hard , but gameplay is elementary and common. Nothing original here. If this game came with fully painted miniatures it would increase the fun factor considerably. I bought my like new copy for $30 at a flea market, which seems about right for what you're getting. I think I'll probably give it to my 12 yr old grandson. This game wouldn't make my top 300. Needs another layer of complexity and better components to really make it a decent game. As is, not worth the effort. Update. I sold it and gave my grandson a good game.
Played Steam version only

Update: FEB 2025 - 

Despite the noise about how confrontational the game is, the strategy in this game is so linear, edging towards utterly boring. 2 stars.

Weird for a troops-on-a-map to have significant number of decisions that are very solitaire-ish. Indeed a hybrid, but this is leaning a lot on the terrible modern Euro design

Great hybrid game of pure tactical romp! The card drafting is weak, due to how incredibly linear it is. But the overall concoction of this design is fantastic that leads to good gameplay.
Think I would rather just play Chaos in the Old World for this style of game or Fire & Axe for the theme...
Gift

Blood Rage is a game that I really wanted to love, felt destine to love, didn't love and wondered if something was wrong with me. Nope, my friends are wrong. This game is garbage. At best, Blood Rage has been a flaming disappointment and here's why.

In all of its ball-tickling grandeur, Blood Rage is a construct of stitched together uninteresting subsystems that are primarily driven by an overstretched card drafting mechanic. Perhaps the most obvious is combat which is resolved by an unimaginative card-reveal. This completely subverts the battle driven, glory-seeking theme and reduces it to a game of high card victory point grabbing but only if you win or lose in tandem with what you drafted prior.

Don't get me wrong, if you like planning, drafting and implementing combos within a chaotic context, this game is perfect for you. The BGG meta is certainly filled with combo discussions and critiques.

For me, Blood Rage is filled with so much action devaluation that I can't even enjoy my own cleverness and the only remedy seems to be playing it more.

In der richtigen Konstellation, und mit einigen Flaschen Met, ist Blood Rage sicherlich ein großartiges Spiel.

Mich stört: Fast jedes noch so gut vorbereitete Plünderungs-Vorhaben kann durch eine (oder mehrere) Karte(n) des Gegners zunichte gemacht werden.

Die einzige Möglichkeit hier gewappnet zu sein, ist die Karten der jeweiligen Zeitalter gut zu kennen. Ansonsten wird es auch für gute Verlierer schnell frustrierend! Dies scheinen die Autoren auch durchaus berücksichtigt zu haben: Denn es gibt nicht allzu viele Karten und selbst durch die Erweiterungen scheint hier nichts Wesentliches hinzu gekommen zu sein. Und dennoch:

Habe ich den Elan Blood Rage so oft zu spielen, um den oben geschilderten Sachverhalt abzuschwächen? Nein.

Habe ich diese Dinge wieder vergessen, wenn das Spiel mal drei, vier Monate nicht auf den Tisch kommt (was sehr wahrscheinlich ist)? Ja.

Das Spielbrett sieht furchtbar aus, der Rest geht grafisch in Ordnung.

A surprisingly solid card drafting game unfortunately held back by awful card balance that requires all players to be very experienced with the game to self-correct the balance issues by metagaming the draft, otherwise one player will rocket way ahead of the others. When the stars align and you have the perfect group for it, Blood Rage is actually pretty fun but more often then not the game has played out with a runaway leader that assembled the wombo combo (either via luck of the draw or by other players failing to hate draft them) that's just a dull experience for everyone involved.

My worst gaming experience.

I was so thrilled to test this game; I wanted to buy everything. Then, I played my first game, and I was glad I hadn't bought it. It was really an awful and frustrating game experience, even though the game had everything I like: deckbuilding, minis, area control...

It didn't work for me. The winner wins by suiciding all their units. You cannot move your boats or giant sea monster; mine was sitting there doing nothing throughout the entire game. And beware, it's not a conquest game; it's an area control game.

Personally, this board game is my biggest disappointment.
Upgrade to upgrade your upgrades Rage
I don't get why people like this. Perhaps the miniatures? Certainly not the gameplay. The cards and battles are way too random.

Making one strategy better then all the others made the game only be about "hate" drafting which took the fun out of the game.

I find all of the Cool Mini or Not (CMON) games to be unbalanced but this is the one of those I've played I had the least fun with because of it.
Very random, some strategies cannot be countered.

Blood Rage scratches an itch I don't have. A game that achieves its design goals quite well yet I care neither for its parts or sum.

I'm not a fan of card drafting, card combos, special powers, or compounding abilities toward bigger badder moves. I find the game is largely about the draft and moving up the 3 tech tracks with the board as a stage for these things to play out. Early scoring is small and secondary to moving up the tracks and gaining upgrades toward bigger scoring opportunities in round 3.

I'd suggest drafting/buying cards Dominion style (the game is essentially deck-building/hand mgt from age-to-age) but I doubt it would significantly alter my feelings. As it is, drafting prevents AP and downtime but at the cost of increased luck into a very significant part of the game.

I understand why it's popular: shiny bits, fantasy theme, euro point maximizer underneath; ultimately a familiar song with a new arrangement. It feels like 7 Wonders and Cosmic Encounter but played out on a board with Viking dudes. I bet the Dice Tower crowd is nuts for this.

A funny aside, despite all the shiny chrome I never really felt the theme. Instead I found it easy to ignore in favor of maximizing points. But hey it's a euro with a lot of chrome.

I really dislike this game. I don't enjoy hidden information in a game that only lasts a mere 3 rounds. Seems like one failure can be quite costly.

Prefer Bunny Kingdom for a drafting game. Prefer cry havoc for an area control game.
Can't mention one thing I enjoyed about this game. Ugly board, prone to snowballing, repetitive as hell... So many better games out there.
Much prefer Rising Sun.
What is the hype all about? All style and no substance.
Just not a fun game. Had all the expansions even...

Blood Rage would just be a whole lot more fun if you streamlined out the whole map, area control and actions elements - Victory is 80%+ decided in the draft anyway so why not just make it a pure drafting game instead of wasting half an hour evaluating the draft through other mechanisms.

Interesting game. After a drafting round, you have the opportunity to spend "rage" for actions such as occupy a territory or plunder. Winner is the player with the most victory points at the end of the game.
The first plays were a lot better but I reckon that the replayability is just not given in this game because it is very obvious that some cards are extremely stronger than other ones. That has the negative effect of predicting the winner of the game.
Aside from that, the game is enjoyable although it is quite repetitive in its actions, in the end there is not much variability.
After all I would still recommend this since I am the only one in my "gamer circle" which is fed up with this, the others still enjoy it

Something about the game feels very forced, which isn't a feeling I get when playing a similar game in Inis.

Another case of wanting to like it more than I do. What I want is a raucous, stompy conflict game that lives up to a name like "Blood Rage", but instead what I got was a dreary euro with a tedious draft, anticlimactic battles, and a lot of heads-down upgrade management.

People like to bring up runaway leader problems for games that don't deserve it, but this is a rare exception where I think the critique is justified. There is almost no compensation given to losing armies in regards to board state or action economy, and the winners are unilaterally rewarded with increases in both. Early pillage winners can just feel unstoppable at times. When every player is perfectly checking the power of every other player the system works, but the balance is too delicate.

The minis also add to the cost but don't add to the game, and the depiction of women in an exclusively female tribe all clad in fur bikinis feels really slimy for a game that came out in 2015. There's no excuse for that kind of stuff anymore.
Abstract. pasted on Viking theme. Overhyped with minis.

I am a little bit dissapointed after the first play. It was meant to be quick, but we spent almost 4 hours. It was unclear who the leader is, and the winner was unexpected. Beautiful components - espacially monsters - but the whole game is in my opinion overhyped, not even in the same league with Forbidden Stars or GoT.

Interesting, thematic and well produced game. There are good game mechanics. Winning fights gives you much less glory than losing the fights, which is really counter intuitive.

Lay it on thick! Blood Rage offers drafting followed by combat on nine fields plus 4 fjords. With usual equipment, the game would actually look quite plain. The opulent equipment makes it an eye-catcher, but apart from that (except for the price) it doesn't contribute much, because the game doesn't tell a story. The mechanism itself is quite entertaining: The drafting invites tactical considerations, the combat offers many surprises and there are various ways to victory. Nevertheless, the game sometimes leaves you puzzled: The imponderables seem large and at the same time a lead in rage seems unassailable.
It's a very rough gameplay and boring.
My only thought while playing this game is "Why am I playing this when Inis exists?"

I've only played once digitally. The card driven gameplay is a lot more euro-y than I expected from a dudes on a map game. I am happy to play it in person to see if it improves my first impression. Drafting against AI is no fun.

Blood Rage is a game that didn't quite hit the spot for me. I came in expecting a game much heavier in combat due to it's theme and naming, and the actual combat, while passable, isn't engaging. Most of the dominant strategy revolves more around the cards in your hand or sacrificing your own warriors. I like the drafting mechanic, and the rage limitation makes you really agonize over your decisions. But I still don't find the total gameplay loop super engaging.
Overall, while I can see the appeal, Blood Rage didn't quite hit the spot for me due to lackluster combat, as well as one or two dominant strategies ruining replayability. I will still play if offered, but not a game I typically look forward to breaking out during game night.
Simon

You can win by losing battles. It's solid game if everyone is in the same level, otherwise experienced players will have a great advantage.

best with 4

Mostly a fun game. The mechanics, however, ensure that most of the time the final scoring is not close at all with a runaway leader becoming apparent after the second round.
Includes a terrible scoring mechanic which makes no sense with the theme of the game

The theme is cool, but honestly I thought the beginning of the game was a lot more interesting than the end. As everyone amass more rage and horns, people can simply flood each province with their own army and pillage without anyone being able to add any units. We also played the no draft version, and by sheer luck I happened to draw a bunch of cards that worked with each other (Loki’s blessing with backstab, eminence and even the glorious death quest). Although I didn’t get to play all of them because someone ended the age prematurely, but I could have finished the round with a lot of points not because I did anything clever. Ultimately I was disappointed by how one dimensional the gameplay is and it is pretty repetitive, upgrade, play quest, pillage and repeat. There really isn’t much here and I’m truly surprised at how highly rated it is.

The major issue I have with this game is the lack of asymmetry between the viking clans. The good thing about this game is how many different mechanics it blends together. With the right group, it is a gem and leads to some tense moments with the combat cards.

An average Dudes-On-The-Map game with lots of playability due to the numerous abilities and monsters to use in the game. It's surprisingly very easy to teach since all the information is both on the cards and playmat. In terms of pacing, it plays pretty quickly since you are able to do only ONE action per turn instead of multiple (more board games need to do this). The game ends shortly after the climax and doesn't overstay its welcome.

However, I don't feel the "need" to own this game.

The first glaring problem with the game is the simple fact that you need to know the decks inside out to play at any competent level. Otherwise, the game just feels like you are along for the ride with no real direction to follow. I've seen experienced players take advantage of their neighboring newbies because of newbies didn't realize that passing certain cards to him would just make him powerful.

Another problem is the numerous effects that make it hard to decipher the game state. Throughout the session, you will encounter card effects that seem to give you points for doing almost random thing such as dying, or other people dying, or losing a fight, etc. Unlike the younger brother Rising Sun, there doesn't seem to be any focus within the game. You have vikings, stuff happens, and you score points. In Rising Sun, while there are effects that give you points, the game still forces everyone to be on the same page about gathering monsters, building strongholds, and taking over areas.

With all the faults, the game does have sparks in its design. It plays quickly, the downtime is minimal, and it's very easy to comprehend the core basics of the game. Unlike many other games, I feel the expansions like the Mystics and Gods actually hurt the game instead of improving it.

Didn't realize this till I owned a copy, but honestly I'm embarrassed to play a board game with action figures as pawns and while the game/mechanisms are really pretty decent, gameplay is compelling enough and strategic enough to have enjoyed myself, it's not strong enough to transcend my toy aversion.
Mediocre and overproduced. Play Inis instead.
Ареакнотрол, похож на иниш и игру престолов, не зашло, но миньки классные
ausgeliehen
Some people are really into it. It's alright to me, but would rather play something else. Don't play with someone that has played it a lot. You'll get trashed.
Tried to like this game, but felt very random. Very little you do seem to matter when someone can have a lucky draw in the final draft. This feels like the blue-shell in mariokart

One play of it thus far. There was something odd about this one. The card you draft matter a lot, but there's not a lot of agency on which ones you'll pick up, and the discarding of cards at the end made it look like the deck isn't very tightly designed.
During the game, some players were essentially forced to win fights which would earn the loser a lot of points and it felt like there was very little the 'winner' could do about it. It was failing to be a good area control game and became more of a card game with a board. In the final round, it didn't feel like there were many interesting decisions being made either.
This game definitely felt like it could have used more time for development into a much tighter and engaging game.

Sure it rewards creating a meta around it but forget about teaching a new player to play and not absolutely destroying them. Then when you actually do give the game lots of plays it becomes about hate drafting what cards your opponents need because if you don’t certain strategies can run away with the game. It is a well made game but I think the actual play of it is rather mediocre. Drafting is much better in other games where more complexity in strategies and wider paths to success exist.

The mechanics of Blood Rage are quite interesting and I usually quite enjoy the game when I play it. But after 5 plays (all 4 player games), I find that I tend to leave the table unsatisfied and frustrated.

I think the main issue I have is that there are too few cards - I've seen them all, and they fall a bit too neatly in a few synergistic groups. I think that adding more cards to the total pool (but keeping the number of cards players keep) would really make the game more interesting to me, as you would not know exactly which cards are in play - and there would be a greater chance of "new" strategies appearing, rather than different people picking from the 3-4 existing paths every game.

Then again, I've found myself often thinking "Huh, maybe it's time to give blood rage another go...?".
Box wear; fully sleeved.

This was my first 'serious game' I bought after Catan.

The first few plays were really fun, but over time I got tired of it (maybe because it was the only option I had and I just played it too much).

A few things bother me:

'Rage' feels like it runs out way too fast. Every game I feel very limited in how much I can actually do.

I like seeing a board full of miniatures. But because of all the battles, a lot of minis go to Valhalla too quickly, and the board usually feels pretty empty.

Monsters feel not as scary and big as they look.

Three rounds feel a bit short. I’d love to have at least four.

Still, the game is pretty fun and the minis are beautiful (that was honestly the main reason I bought it). I had a really good time with it. Recently I even got nostalgic and played three games in a row with a friend. So I think the real solution is just to buy more games, so there’s always another option and people are more willing to play.

I'm not a fan of the Viking theme and I have my political concerns regarding the popularity of this theme in general, but Blood Rage is nonetheless a fun experience. It's quite abstract and the card drafting seems to be half of the actual game. The following area control half is more like the playing out phase of the drafted cards, which puts an emphasis on strategy, not on tactics. I often find myself not having enough room for reacting to my opponents' actions, which makes it less interactive to me. The drafting phase though is really great. I love the trade offs between unit upgrades, scoring, and battle cards.

Update: Played again after 8 years. It doesn't hold up for me anymore. Rising Sun is still my favorite of the OG CMON line, but Ankh is very good too. Blood Rage is just outdated feeling and needs a rules refresh and some mechanism updates.

When looking at EL’s progression I can see something of CitOW and Rising Sun here. Blood Rage is a good game, but it doesn’t quite rise to the spheres of Chaos in the Old World. On the other hand it also doesn’t dive into the torpor of full table Rising Sun. The excellent action point system comes directly from CitOW and as the players are at the start of the clan tracks in the beginning it starts rather interestingly. Even with only three rounds the game however starts to drag a bit towards the end if there is even a hint of AP proneness in the air. I do like the whole Loki concept balancing the game and offering another approach to gaining glory. On the con side the balance is cracking towards the end of the game with huge point swings especially thanks to the clan tracks. The game also suffers from the Langian syndrome of the cool things being the least useful if your aim is to do well.

The card drafting is well implemented, giving asymmetric powers to every player and every game feels different. High quality miniatures. On the other hand, I dislike the lack of attrition in battles : the winner keeps all his figures, the victory points and the stats increase. The loser loses all of his figures. (Sold to Markey)

Игра прикольная! С каждой эпохой ваши карты становятся мощнее, сами игроки развиваются и набирают силу, а тем временем поле сужается сподвигая вас к конфликту, но при этом эффекты карт боя\улучшений сделаны таким образом, что вам даже интересно умирать и получать выгоду! В итоге, никто не боится сражаться, каждый считает себя победителем, тот кто хотел проиграть = проиграл, а второй игрок добился своих целей и получил очки + улучшения и каждый раз выбор вступать в битву или нет, не очевиден, ведь вы хотите ещё исполнить волю богов или сохранить ярость, чтобы перейти в локацию с рагнароком и получить дополнительных очков!
Мне игра понравилась, для закрепления моих впечатлений надо бы сыграть ещё партейку, т.к в этой партии я победил через самую легкую тактику "Локи" , мне в каждой эпохе на драфте достались карты, которые дают очки за вернувшихся воинов из Вальгаллы, а потому я был счастлив проигранным битвам и получал много очков, в последнем раунде получил по 6 очков за 7 убитых моих фигурок! = 42 ПО.

It's a good game, but I feel you can lose the game in Round 1 in a kind of intransparent way. So the easy and lightweight rules are in contrast to having to warn new players. Each rules teach I do basically comes with
- "don't play too many expensive upgrades because some Loki Player will kick you out of the round before you did anything"
- "Look out especially if you play with Loki cards to not forget playing your upgrade cards before all Provinces are pillaged".

Basically, you can lose the game as early as your own turn 3. There is no comeback from not getting any Upgrades in Round 1. With experienced games, you quickly come into a stressful meta game of having to memorize all cards and combos or be crushed from misplays.

Blood rage is an odd one for me. The design is a cool mix, and games are a great length with endless interaction, which I appreciate. There's a lot of different ways to approach the game, and you're extremely invested in what your opponents are doing. Lots of tension in the action selection as well, making every move count.

It starts to feel samey pretty quickly to me however. I also find it frustrating to play, because it rewards meta knowledge of the deck so much, and battles never end the way you think they will. Going into a fight with a lot of power for an area you need only to realize that it would have been stronger to lose, or not fight at all, just leaves a sour taste. A war game this is not. It's an intensely chaotic, tactical, point salad drafting game at it's heart, with area control and conflict tacked on as scoring mechanisms. I see why people love it, but it's too swingy, unpredictable, and draft focused for my taste. I also find the board to be very messy. Which does fit with the vibe of the game I suppose.

I always think I'm down to play it again, like there's something I'm just not clicking with, I just never really have the fun I'm hoping for. But sure, let's play again.

A pretty competent game which takes up quite a lot of space with minis. It's 90+% minis. That being said, the area control and push your luck elements (do you go all in on Yggdrasil, or stay on the perimeter and outlast everyone?) make this a thrilling game to play with others. When you go all in and bust, you knew the risks.
On the other hand, the Loki strategy being overpowered is one of the worst parts of the game. The "win by losing" strategy being not just viable but so good it's impossible to win without hate drafting just does not sit well with me.

I think maybe it's lost it's luster over time, but I'm still excited to play it again. The draft is the real game, and the execution of your draft more a followup or implementation of your strategy rather than a tactical decision space. It certainly suffers from a steep experience curve, as someone who has played the game previously will have a distinct advantage over newer players. I've also had perks bounce pretty hard off the game, feeling that certain cards and combinations are overpowered. I can see that, but ultimately it comes down to that draft and whether everyone at the table knows what can and will happen if they let certain cards go around the table. Managing your money/rage level to ensure that you don't action your way out of doing things in your turn is a fun little twist, and gives singer agency on whether timing of certain plays is more important than the quantity of actions in a given turn.

I think it would be best served as a game that is played regularly by the same play group.

There are so many different strategies in this game that you never truly know who will come out victorious. Viable winning options include winning clan battles, controlling multiple areas, and completing quests. Even dying or losing battles is a great winning strategy if you draft the right cards.

The miniature figures are really nice, and even more incredible when painted. I would like to get more plays of this to hammer down some other strategies. Really really good action point and area control game that has a great wargame theme and feel.

I'll play this game whenever asked. It's a fantastic and quick (for area control) card drafting game. My group has played MTG for years and picked up on a lot of the drafting strategies quickly. It's really the meat of the game and the card play is strategic without feeling like a chore. Highly recommend for competitive gamers who enjoy conflict

Blood Rage – Few games capture the glory of battle and the poetry of destruction quite like this Viking epic. As Ragnarok looms, rival clans fight for dominance across a dying world, earning glory through conquest, quests, and the occasional glorious death. The rules are simple, but the strategy runs deep — drafting powerful cards to upgrade your clan, summon monstrous allies, and sway the gods themselves. Every decision feels meaningful, every loss potentially part of a greater plan. It’s elegant, explosive, and endlessly replayable — the game that made Vikings cool again (and reminded everyone that mead and mayhem are a perfect mix). Skål!

Great graphic design. Clear but thematic spaces on the game board. Your player board doubles as a player aid for the different turn actions.

 Many equally valid paths to victory, all leaving room to sabotage other players' well-laid plans, or to bluff about your own intentions.

 It looks way more complicated than it is. Rules are easy to explain.

----

 A skeptic could say this is an overproduced game.

 Experienced players often have the upper hand over new players due to their knowledge of the types of cards that are in the decks. The first time(s) you play, you're mostly familiarizing yourself with the different ways to win rather than really having a shot at winning against more experienced. I've seen this discourage some new players.

Nihilistic vikings, whose biggest death wish is to go down, or better, rise up to Walhalla in a blaze of glory? A PUBG-like Ragnarök mechanism destroying and shrinking the board every round? Epic Yggdrasil fights, where everything and everybody gets involved and the winner takes it all?

Count me in, this sounds like a hell lot of stupid fun!

Blood Rage brought me back to board games and opened my eyes for the trashy side. It's a diceless hybrid leaning towards Euro with victory points, strong drafting and tableau-building elements and bla, still it's somehow thematic, powerful, dynamic and a blast to play. In the best possible way everything is swingy and broken and wombo combo in this rather chaotic game and it feels enormously satisfying to feel the impact and synergies of your actions.

Behind all overproduced bombast and martial slaughter there is a clever tactical and overall mostly balanced area control game, which I full heartedly enjoy and recommend.

As everyone is pointing out, the Loki strategy is kinda op/lame. While it's interesting gameplaywise and I'm glad it's there, it's too easy to capitalize on it with little effort. Still everybody has to play around it and it's rare the Loki player is winning at our table even though he's also never getting last. It is an issue, but not big enough to dumb down my enthusiasm.
Best 4, Recommend 3

This is my favorite game, I've played it more than 10 times. The setup is easy with few components, the play time is not to long but just perfect, and there are so many tactical choices to make without reading any long complicated text on cards.
The tension is always there.
Although I have the 5-player expansion, I have every time only played it with 4 players, which is really good.

One of the best area control games ever, highly strategic, lol randomnes
An intensely strategic game, packed with suspense and excitement all the way through. You only need to play it a few times to fully enjoy it. (updated 9.5 >> 10)
This hybrid area control rich in theme and card play is Incredible with 3 to 5 players. Suffers a little at 2 but it’s still playable. One of my favorite games ever made.
#area

What’s not to love about this game. The art is great, all the unique cards are awesome. The theme is fun. The drafting works great! Awesome figures. I got a custom insert which I think helps tremendously. Love the game.

Everyone had a great time! The rules seemed fairly simple at first, but there was actually a lot of nuanced situations we needed to look up. Very much looking forward to more plays. This could be a real winner for our group!

The strategic and tactical decisions are all very enjoyable. After the first few plays, the shock of the overpowered cards subsides and you play expecting them, so you lose a little of that initial chaotic fun.

5 plays, 9.0 - This game is amazing. So tense. So hard to decide the best action in many scenarios. Just the right amount of unpredictability. And because it's the players that are unpredictable instead of the game, it doesn't feel like bad luck. Such a fun experience. Though I have not yet had a game under 2 hours.

Probably my favourite game.

7th play, 4 player - First time playing with 4 players in nearly three years. I still love this game. The drafting is great, helping form your round by round strategy, but then the board play is so juicy, unpredictable and chaotic, you're just holding on hoping you can finish your plans. The way it build up to your big point scoring opportunities in round 3 is very satisfying. Feeling might be somewhat bolstered by the fact that I've won 6 of 7 games.

10.0 - 8th play, 4 player - Such a close and tense game. The newbies beat the experienced players!

I always enjoy playing this one. The Kickstarter monsters allow even more tactics to hone or counter strategies and add to the replayability. While I wish that the Kickstarter exclusives were made more readily available, I still love the choices in the basic game. Drafting the right cards for your strategy is important, as well as paying attention to what your opponent's strategy seems to be. This one has never disappointed me. Recommended for 3-4 players.

BLOOD RAGE!! What a great game. At one point it was my favorite of all time, but I have since cooled. It could definitely make it's way back up, but as of right now I have not been able to have any real competitive games as I am always teaching new gamers. I hope that people want to play and master it, that way I can really get some competitive games 3-5 player games of Blood Rage. Love the minis and production, CMON standard here. Eric Lang's best.
